abstract.p: Letter from Sen Jon S Corzine and Repr Luis V Gutierrez on their legislation to require wire transfer service providers to disclose all costs for remittance transactions, which are common among immigrants sending money back to relatives

block.p: We agree with you about the need for immediate improvements to the global remittance system (''Dollars Without Borders,'' editorial, some editions, May 13).

We should provide incentives that encourage banks and credit unions to expand the availability and affordability of foreign remittances. This would not only make remittances less costly but also bring a large part of America's unbanked population into the financial mainstream, making it easier to establish a credit history, buy a car or obtain a mortgage.
We agree with you about the need for immediate improvements to the global remittance system (''Dollars Without Borders,'' editorial, some editions, May 13).

We should provide incentives that encourage banks and credit unions to expand the availability and affordability of foreign remittances. This would not only make remittances less costly but also bring a large part of America's unbanked population into the financial mainstream, making it easier to establish a credit history, buy a car or obtain a mortgage.

But until that broad access is achieved, safeguards must be in place to prevent those who seek to send money to loved ones abroad from being victimized by unscrupulous business practices or saddled with exorbitant fees.

We have introduced companion legislation in the Senate and the House that would require wire transfer service providers to provide consumers with full disclosure of the costs, surcharges and exchange rate used in connection with remittance transactions.
JON S. CORZINE LUIS V. GUTIERREZ Washington, May 13, 2004
The writers are members of, respectively, the Senate Banking Committee and the House Financial Services Committee.
